physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Two asymptomatic children (aged 12 and 14) with nonfunctioning pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors more than 2 cm in size. The 14-year-old had mild hypercalcemia and hyperprolactinemia, with plasma prolactin levels at 3676 mU/liter.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The pancreatic tumor in the 14-year-old girl grew from less than 2 cm to 2.1 cm over two years, after which a partial pancreatectomy was performed. The 12-year-old girl remained asymptomatic but was found to have a pancreatic mass of 3.3 cm by age 12, leading to a distal pancreatectomy at follow-up. Both patients were well at the 12-month follow-up.
